labels.name: duplicate
labels.description: This issue or pull request already exists

labels.name: wontfix
labels.description: This will not be worked on

issues.title: Q-bit: little or no new information?
issues.author: dtikhonov
issues.body:
> For QUIC v1 connections, the attacker can examine offsets in STREAM frames to determine whether packet number skips are deliberate, so Q-bit signal provides little new information.

Why "little" instead of "no?"  AFAICT, the Q-bit provides no new information.

comments.author: igorlord
comments.body:
I was worried that someone will have some far-fetched objection to "no", which would lead a rat hole for the discussion.  For example, there may be cases when a lost packet had a STREAM frame for a new stream, so it would not be noticed.

But I may actually agree to "no", since what we care about is a signal that something has definitely been lost.  The example above only informs that something might be lost (but likely is a deliberate skip).

comments.author: dtikhonov
comments.body:
My problem with the current phrasing, "provides little new information," is that it leads the reader to ask "*what* new information does the Q bit provide?"  This is not covered in the draft.  I'd replace "little" with "no" for clarity.

Another way to handle this is to rephrase along these lines:

> The information exposed by the square wave value with regard to artificial packet number gaps can be gleaned by other means.  For example, the attacker can analyze offsets in STREAM frames to detect holes.

Since this discussion is in the context of an opt-ACK attack, which requests a large resource, this makes sense.

comments.author: ferrieux
comments.body:
In the same vein, but in the introductory paragraph of the same section, isn't the sentence "_...does not provide any information that cannot be observed by simply counting packets_" a bit of an overstatement ? Wouldn't the devil's advocate say something like "Then why do you need it in the first place ?" ?

What about "provides very little information over what can be gleaned from simply counting packets" ?

comments.author: dtikhonov
comments.body:
> Since this discussion is in the context of an opt-ACK attack, which requests a large resource, this makes sense.

I take it back.  When thinking about this originally, I had HTTP/3 in mind specifically.  In HTTP/3, a large resource is delivered using a single stream.  Future application protocols that use QUIC may use multiple streams and so the "look for STREAM holes" is not applicable.  @igorlord's [comment above](https://github.com/igorlord/draft-ferrieuxhamchaoui-tsvwg-lossbits/issues/7#issuecomment-572699499) sort of touches on this.

comments.author: igorlord
comments.body:
@dtikhonov, I think the key is whether the attacker is able to get the peer to send a single very large stream.  If so, the attacker has a reliable way to identify lost packets.  If not, it becomes harder for the attacker to replicate signal quality available from the Q bit.

@ferrieux Your comment about the first sentence makes sense. I'll reword it.

comments.author: igorlord
comments.body: Resolved via #12

issues.title: Including skipped packet number into Q run
issues.author: dtikhonov
issues.body:
> However, an endpoint that implements {{DATAGRAM}} and uses a loss-based congestion controller MAY include deliberately skipped packet numbers in the current Q run.

This is confusing.  What does it mean to include skipped packet numbers in the Q run?

I suggest using a more explicit recommendation.  For example:

> To make skipped packet numbers indistinguishable from packet loss, a sender MAY shorten the current Q run by the number of skipped packets.  For example, skipping a single packet number will invert the sQuare wave one outgoing packet sooner.

comments.author: igorlord
comments.body: I like this. I do think this is still valuable to mention {{DATAGRAM}} and loss-based congestion controller.  (We can discuss this, of course).

comments.author: dtikhonov
comments.body: I think it's better if you made this change -- I think you have a better grasp of the concepts involved.

comments.author: ferrieux
comments.body:
Chiming in 4 days late, sorry: Isn't the sentence "_...does not provide any information that cannot be observed by simply counting packets_" a bit of an overstatement ? Wouldn't the devil's advocate say something like "Then why do you need it in the first place ?" ?

What about "provides very little information over what can be gleaned from simply counting packets" ?

comments.author: dtikhonov
comments.body: That's a good observation -- it deserves its own issue.

comments.author: ferrieux
comments.body: Oh, right, wrong thread. I added it to the end of #7 , which seems to be better suited.

comments.author: igorlord
comments.body: Resolved via #12

issues.title: Settle on the use of the definite article
issues.author: dtikhonov
issues.body:
Sometimes the draft uses the definite article when taking about the Q and L bits (e.g. "The Q-bit signal does not provide...") and sometimes it does not (e.g "To use Q-bit for this purpose").

We should pick one way of doing it and stick with it.

I am not a native speaker.  That being said, I believe in most places where "the" is omitted, it should be used.

comments.author: igorlord
comments.body:
Omg.  This is my worst nightmare -- getting the articles right.  None of us are native speakers. LOL.
I think you are right.  Could you fix this?

I might show this to native speakers closer to when we are done and ask them to fix the articles.  I might use my kid for this. :)

comments.author: dtikhonov
comments.body:
I'll make a PR and do my  best.

Using child labor is a good idea, +1.

comments.author: igorlord
comments.body: Resolved in PR #13

issues.title: Consistent use of dashes: Q-bit or Q bit?
issues.author: dtikhonov
issues.body:
Let's settle on one way and make the draft consistent in this regard.

My preference would be _not_ to use the dash.

comments.author: igorlord
comments.body:
I am ok with that.

A related issue is the use of "QL bits" vs "loss bits".  What's your take on that?

comments.author: dtikhonov
comments.body:
One issue with the naming I've been having (in my code) regarding "QL bits" vs "QL loss bits" vs "loss bits" is that L is the loss bit and, at the same time, together they are loss bits.

Certainly, the expression "loss bits" is a better name for the Draft.  (Compare with "QL bits.")  One way to approach this is to rename the L "the **Loss** event bit" to E "the loss **Event** bit.  Then Q and E together will be the loss bits.

Short of that, I'd drop the use of "QL bits" in favor of "loss bits" everywhere in the draft.

comments.author: igorlord
comments.body: I think I've replaced "loss bit" with "loss event bit" everywhere before.  I'd say we ought to keep "Loss event bit" L, since it is very mnemonic.  Replacing "QL-?bits with" "loss bits" seems right.

comments.author: dtikhonov
comments.body: I'll make a PR for this.

issues.title: 0x1055 is not a valid TP number
issues.author: igorlord
issues.body: Not valid per "QUIC Transport Parameter Registry" in the transport draft, since 0x1055 == 134*31+27.  Damn, there was a 26/27 chance, and we blew it!

comments.author: dtikhonov
comments.body:
Wow, good catch!

Too bad: "loss" is an excellent mnemonic device.  One the bright size, "lost" is only 2 away: 0x1057.

comments.author: ferrieux
comments.body:
@igorlord: you mean 30/31 but, indeed, too bad :)

Out of curiosity: where does this blacklisting of 27 modulo 31 come from ?

comments.author: igorlord
comments.body:
@dtikhonov Let's go with 0x1057.

@ferrieux The specific formula -- do not remember where it came from.

comments.author: igorlord
comments.body: Resolved via #16

issues.title: What happens to L in DATAGRAM mode ?
issues.author: ferrieux
issues.body:
While considering opt-ack mitigation and the possible associated noise on Q, the distinction between normal (STREAM) and DATAGRAM modes came up. As it turns out, an "unpolluted" Q is of concern only for DATAGRAM (since for stream, stream progression gives the same info).

Now, how would the L bit be computed in the DATAGRAM case ? L is supposed to be low-hanging fruit for a "loss detection machinery", which is the algorithm driving the lifecycle of packets in the retrans queue. But DATAGRAMs don't have a retrans queue, right ?

If it turns out that L cannot be defined for DATAGRAM, we may be better off disabling lossbits altogether in that case. Ipso facto, in the STREAM case, noisy-Q (decrement when mitigating opt-ack) is unneeded. 

Am I missing something ?

comments.author: igorlord
comments.body: I do not understand the problem.  DATAGRAM is an ACK-eliciting frame (it has to be for the congestion controller to work).  So loss of packets containing DATAGRAMs is known to the sender (who will likely not retransmit lost DATAGRAMs, but that's an orthogonal concern).

comments.author: dtikhonov
comments.body: I agree with Igor:  A lost packet is a lost packet.

comments.author: ferrieux
comments.body: OK, but being ACK-eliciting does not imply full lifecycle handling like would be needed for a retrans queue. If the API uses QUIC packet numbers as identifiers (one in return from a "send", and one passed to the ack callback), then the stack itself can remain entirely stateless. In this case, there is no such thing as a timer deciding that a given PN is lost. For L to work, this logic must then be added.

comments.author: igorlord
ferrieux
comments.body:
Oh, you mean that the DATAGRAM frames must keep enough state (similar to retrans queue entries) until their ACK arrives in order to feed the congestion control ? Ok, i n that case, indeed, L is a no-brainer, since these entries will have an expiration timeout (at which time an L=1 is emitted).

Now, in a QUIC-in-QUIC (or TCP-in-QUIC) scenario, where QUIC datagrams encapsulate an L4 with its own congestion control, I guess we want the container-QUIC's congestion control to be disabled. In that case, will the entry expiration timeout still exist ?

comments.author: igorlord
comments.body:
> Oh, you mean that the DATAGRAM frames must keep enough state [...].

Yes, except congestion state (and hence ACKing) is "attached" not to QIUC frames (like DATAGRAM) but to QUIC packets.

> Now, in a QUIC-in-QUIC (or TCP-in-QUIC) scenario, [...]

This is no different from any A-in-B scenario.  Both inner and outer protocols operate independently from each other (other the other protocol enforcing some PMU on the inner protocol).  Of course, depending on B, A may experience "interesting" network properties.

comments.author: ferrieux
comments.body:
> Both inner and outer protocols operate independently from each other

Well, cascading two BBRs or two Cubics is not really desirable, so I imagined some API to disable congestion control in the outer (datagram-bearing) QUIC...

issues.title: organization of the document
issues.author: NicoKos
issues.body:
The document jumps from Introduction to the solution. A motivation section could help design the scope of the observer and what it can see and cannot. 

I think a motivation section could help identifying what is needed and the rationale behind the Q and I bits. 

This would also help in detailing what is the rationale behind each of Q and I.

comments.author: igorlord
comments.body: Thanks for the feedback.  I think we used Introduction largely for motivation.  Is there something you can recommend we talk about in the Motivation section?  Or do you have a suggestion on what to leave in the Introduction and what to move to the Motivation?

comments.author: NicoKos
comments.body: I proposed some text update in PR #36

comments.body: Resolved by #36

Is it relevant to add simple questions in the security section ?

"What can the observer see?"
"Is it possible that an observer correlate past/current connections?"

comments.author: igorlord

comments.author: NicoKos
comments.body: after a better reading of the security section it looks to me that there is no need to go deeper into such details.

issues.title: Add reason for using reserved bits instead of something else
issues.author: igorlord
issues.body:
The alternatives could be:

- lower protocol layers (like CONEX).
- A new "plaintext header extensions mechanism"
- A extra stats-only packet on the path

The answer to all of the above: deployability.  Lower protocol layer extensions do not have network (and minimal OS support, especially for optimized path).  Other QUIC options increase overhead to a point that it is not deployable.

issues.title: Emphasise that loss bits are for monitoring/troubleshooting, not control
issues.author: igorlord
issues.body: Control tends to ossify usage.  Monitoring/troubleshooting -- a lot less.

comments.author: igorlord
comments.body: Resolved by #39

pulls.author: dtikhonov

comments.author: dtikhonov
comments.body: Perhaps a better way to say it is that bit 0x10 is the Q bit and bit 0x08 is the L bit.  This would follow the way the transport draft does it.

reviews.author: ferrieux
reviews.body:
The transport draft unfortunately numbers the bits with 0 as highest ...
Shouldn't it be Q=3, L=4 ?

0 1 2 3 4 5 6 7 
+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+
|0|1|S|R|R|K|P P|
|0|1|S|Q|L|K|P P|

reviews.author: igorlord
reviews.body:
See Section 3.  I call them bit 0x10 and bit 0x08.
Let's stick with QUIC draft nomenclature.

comments.body: I think this is either redundant (clearly the implementation is following this draft by sending this TP) or vague (what exactly does "support" of the extension entail?).  I think PR #5 is a bit more direct about this.

pulls.title: Cleanup of transport param and related QUIC v1 mechanics text
pulls.author: igorlord
pulls.body: Minor cleanup of transport param text.

comments.body: Do you want to include the changes from PR #4 here?
I prefer grouping the QUIC changes introduced by the extension into a single section.  Perhaps "mechanics" is not the right title -- is that why you propose dropping it?
I do not think they are needed. "Supports loss bits extension" (from PR #4) is on its face obvious (how else would it know to send this TP?) and does not add anything else.

Yes.  I did not like "Mechanics" as a section.  If you can come up with a better title and have an intro sentence, make a PR.

Also, would you include "Transport Parameter" section as a subsection to that one?

OK, I'll try to come up with something.

Good point about "Transport Parameter" section.

pulls.title: Use fewer top-level sections
pulls.author: dtikhonov
pulls.body:
This change is good for the following (perhaps subjective) reasons:
1. The changes necessary to use the extension are now in a single section.
1. There are now fewer top-level subsections, which makes ToC looks better.
1. The number of top-level sections is no longer much larger than the number of pages.

The name of the new top-level section, _Implementation_, is better than _Mechanics_ that preceded it.  There may be better choices -- this is just the best I can come up with at the moment.

comments.author: dtikhonov
comments.body: /cc @ferrieux.  (The GitHub UI won't let me add him as a reviewer.)

reviews.author: igorlord
reviews.body: I would s/Implementation/QUIC v1 Implementation/.  I will create a separate PR for this and we can discuss.

pulls.title: Rename Implementation heading
pulls.author: igorlord

pulls.title: Improve Security recommendations
pulls.author: igorlord
pulls.body:
* Be more resolute about "no informaiton" (Issue #7)
* Clarify shortening Q run (Issue #8)

comments.body: I have to take back what I said earlier about removing packet protection:  The attacker _does_ need to remove it to get the packet number.  It is the packet payload that does not need to be decrypted in this case (to get at holes in STREAM frames).

The attacker needs to remove _header_ protection.  It does _not_ need to remove _packet_ protection when Q bit signal is available.  So I believe the text here is correct.  (The terminology used in the transport draft is _packet_ protection, not _payload_ protection.)
Ah, OK.

pulls.title: Use 0x1057 for TP number, as 0x1055 is illegal.
pulls.author: dtikhonov

pulls.title: Add IANA Considerations
pulls.author: igorlord

comments.author: igorlord
comments.body:
> So, this equates "TP present, and empty" with value 0, both meaning "tolerate receiving", right?

Not exactly.  "TP empty" is not valid, since TP requires an integer parameter. 

> Also, since these are varints, value 0 may be represented as 0x00, 0x4000, 0x80000000 or 0xC000000000000000, right (though I guess those subnormal varints are discouraged) ?

Yes.  That's how varints work.  Since pretty much everything in QUIC is varint, it sees best to stick with this (especially since it allows for a 1-byte encoding of what we care about: 0 and 1).

reviews.author: ferrieux
reviews.body:
So, this equates "TP present, and empty" with value 0, both meaning "tolerate receiving", right ?
Also, since these are varints, value 0 may be represented as 0x00, 0x4000, 0x80000000 or 0xC000000000000000, right (though I guess those subnormal varints are discouraged) ?

comments.body:
I don't think we need to recap how the transport parameter is used here -- it is done in the _Transport Parameter_ section.  We do something simple instead:

> Specification: Indicates that the endpoint supports receiving or sending loss bits.

I was basing this on the DATAGRAM draft (https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-pauly-quic-datagram-05#section-7).

> Specification:  Indicates that the connection should enable support
      for unreliable DATAGRAM frames.  An endpoint that advertises this
      transport parameter can receive datagrams frames from the other
      endpoint, **up to and including the length in bytes provided in the
      transport parameter.**

I was using the [1wd draft](https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-huitema-quic-1wd-00#section-6) for reference:

```
   Specification: Indicates that the connection should use TimeStamped
   ACK frames
```

@dtikhonov Well, 1wd draft defines a zero-length transport parameter. The DATAGRAM draft defines an integer parameter and asks IANA to mention the meaning of the parameter value in the registry.  We also define an integer parameter...
OK, it seems your preference is stronger than mine -- looks good to me.
Maybe a little stronger, though this is certainly something that could be trivially changed by the WG with 0 consequences to the design. :)
